extendedIngredients.name: carrots
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 large carrots, quartered and thinly sliced

extendedIngredients.name: chicken pieces
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 lb bone-in, skin-on chicken pieces (drum, breast, wing, neck..) I used a whole small rooster

extendedIngredients.name: egg noodles
extendedIngredients.originalString: 12-16 oz egg noodles (keep in mind they expand as they cook)
metaInformation: (keep in mind they expand as they cook)

extendedIngredients.name: fresh thyme
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 tsp dried thyme or 2 sprigs fresh thyme

extendedIngredients.name: onion
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 small onion, halved (or ½ medium onion)

extendedIngredients.name: ground pepper
extendedIngredients.originalString: salt & ground black pepper, to taste

recipes.title: Chicken Noodle Soup

winePairing.pairingText: Chardonnay, Pinot Noir, and Sauvignon Blanc are my top picks for Chicken. White meat is typically paired with white wine as to not overpower the flavor of the meat, so chardonnay and sauvignon blanc are safe choices. Chicken prepared with a tomato sauce or certainly a red wine sauce can and should be served with a red like a pinot noir. The Downton Abbey Countess of Grantham Chardonnay with a 5 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 16 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: Downton Abbey Countess of Grantham Chardonnay
productMatches.description: Our Downton Abbey Chardonnay displays lovely aromas of tropical fruits and subtle oak on the nose, which give way to flavors of citrus and fresh-cut pineapple on a soft, silky palate. The wine's bright characters and luscious mouthfeel continue through a clean, medium finish. The beautifully balanced and food-friendly bottling is the perfect wine choice for you most regal gatherings or spontaneous get-togethers.

recipes.instructions: Separate chicken into pieces (wings, drums, etc) leaving the skin on and trim chicken pieces of excess fat. Next use a heavy knife to whack/cut/chop the chicken along the center of the bones to expose bone marrow and release the iron-rich good stuff into the broth.In a large soup pot (at least 8 Qt pot), combine chicken pieces with 2 bay leaves, 2 pierced garlic cloves and 1 tsp dried thyme. Add 5 quarts water and bring to a boil. Using a large spoon, remove and discard any foam that rises to the top. Reduce heat to a low simmer and cook partially covered for 1 hours. It should be barely bubbling. The chicken meat will be tender and broth will be infused with chicken flavor.Remove chicken pieces and once they are cool enough to handle, separate the meat from the bones (you'll be putting the meat back into the soup later). Discard bones. Cover meat with foil or a lid to keep it from drying out.Strain the broth into a large heat-proof bowl over a sieve lined with a large paper towel.Rinse the now empty pot, and place back over medium heat. Add 2 Tbsp olive oil and saut 3 finely chopped celery sticks, 2 thinly sliced carrots and 1 finely diced onion. Saute over medium heat for 5 minutes or until vegetables are softened.Add chicken broth back to pot and salt and pepper to taste. I added at least 1 Tbsp sea salt and about  tsp pepper. Bring to a light boil and continue cooking another 15 minutes.Add shredded chicken and egg noodles and continue cooking until noodles are cooked through (check the cooking time on your noodles - mine took 20 min).Turn off heat and stir in fresh parsley and dill. Ladle into warm soup bowls.

steps.step: Separate chicken into pieces (wings, drums, etc) leaving the skin on and trim chicken pieces of excess fat. Next use a heavy knife to whack/cut/chop the chicken along the center of the bones to expose bone marrow and release the iron-rich good stuff into the broth.In a large soup pot (at least 8 Qt pot), combine chicken pieces with 2 bay leaves, 2 pierced garlic cloves and 1 tsp dried thyme.

Add 5 quarts water and bring to a boil. Using a large spoon, remove and discard any foam that rises to the top. Reduce heat to a low simmer and cook partially covered for 1 hours. It should be barely bubbling. The chicken meat will be tender and broth will be infused with chicken flavor.

Remove chicken pieces and once they are cool enough to handle, separate the meat from the bones (you'll be putting the meat back into the soup later). Discard bones. Cover meat with foil or a lid to keep it from drying out.Strain the broth into a large heat-proof bowl over a sieve lined with a large paper towel.Rinse the now empty pot, and place back over medium heat.
Add 2 Tbsp olive oil and saut 3 finely chopped celery sticks, 2 thinly sliced carrots and 1 finely diced onion.
Saute over medium heat for 5 minutes or until vegetables are softened.
Add chicken broth back to pot and salt and pepper to taste. I added at least 1 Tbsp sea salt and about  tsp pepper. Bring to a light boil and continue cooking another 15 minutes.

Add shredded chicken and egg noodles and continue cooking until noodles are cooked through (check the cooking time on your noodles - mine took 20 min).Turn off heat and stir in fresh parsley and dill. Ladle into warm soup bowls.
